title: Thursday, 27th June 2019
bodyHTML:
11:04 am

11:11 am
Rightmove PLC (RMV:LSE): Last: 535.90, down 18.1 (-3.27%), High: 547.90, Low: 535.60, Volume: 749.70k
Zruek good afternoon all
BE11:11am

UBS selling.

BE11:11am

Can Rightmove double its share of agent revenues?
No.

11:11 am
BE11:12am

Which is pretty straightforward.

BE11:12am

We forecast Rightmove to capture 8% of agent revenues by 2028E, vs 5% in 2018. This can be driven by a continued shift of print spend online, increase in Rightmove share of online spend, and moderate further declines in agent profitability. We think further declines in agent profitability beyond our base case would be challenging to achieve, without impacting total advertiser numbers.

marktime Yes, Greene King, maintaining sales at the expense of profits ... unable to up prices to counter rising costs
BE11:13am

Is there risk to FY19 consensus revenue growth (+8%) from branch closures?
Yes

11:13 am
BE11:13am

While we expect 8% revenue growth in 2019E, this assumes stable advertiser numbers. UBS Evidence Lab data shows total advertiser numbers were down -2% in March-19 yoy. We note transaction volumes (seasonally adjusted) were down 11% yoy in May-19 (last available data), and are down -3% ytd. This follows a challenging 2018 where agent profitability was under pressure.

BE11:13am

Can Rightmove’s addressable revenue pool grow?Yes, we forecast the commission pool to grow at just 2% p.a. We expect housing transactions to remain depressed with material price inflation constrained by an inflating yield curve and challenged affordability. Further, we expect agent commission rates toremain under pressure in a weak macro environment and from competition from hybrid agents. While a vendor pays model offers upside, we do not think it is likely to gain material traction.

BE11:14am

And you're paying 29x 2019 for it.

marktime Gross margin on a pint never higher, it is paying the girl to pull it which is doing the damage
11:14 am

Which it won't. Probably.

BE11:15am

Given a weak UK housing market (low price growth, commission rates under pressure, declining volumes), we think this will be challenging. Rightmove is trading at a 5yr peak PEG ratio of 2.5x. Weak advertiser numbers in 2019 could be a catalyst for a de-rating, with UBS Evidence Lab data suggesting advertisers were -2% yoy in Mar-19

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Given a weak UK housing market (low price growth, commission rates under pressure, declining volumes), we think this will be challenging. Rightmove is trading at a 5yr peak PEG ratio of 2.5x. Weak advertiser numbers in 2019 could be a catalyst for a de-rating, with UBS Evidence Lab data suggesting advertisers were -2% yoy in Mar-19.

red yes its a lot for rightmove. its one to buy after brexit, hopefully would bring a mark down. highly priced, fine business otherwise
BE11:20am

This is Barclays predicting an aerospace supplier reset post Boeing's difficulties keeping their 737 Max airborne.

BE11:21am

So, moves back to "equal weight" and says 2020 consensus needs to move a lot lower

Punter In knife catching corner, XPS down 38% on its 3/2019 results, numbers difficult to assess it being a pensions admin biz, mention of profits growth to be impacted this year but puzzlingly large fall in price to 100p, Liberum say buy TP 210p, any grey or views?
mtu oh and Easyjet(EZJ)
11:22 am
BE11:22am

We roadshowed the CEO recently,considered emerging commentary on the 737MAX programme at the Paris air show in conjunction with our US A&D team, and now anticipate a widespread‘supplier reset’ with FY20E impact not yet factored intoc onsensus: Senior has the highest exposure to the programme in our coverageuniverse (25% FY19E group sales,pre-rate cuts). Since 13/3 grounding, Spiritsuppliers have continued to produce above rate(57/monthvs Boeing’s cut to 42), which has generated significant inventory build. We thinkthe required backlog burn when deliveries recommence globallywill temper the pace ofproduction returningto full rate(we assume not before FY21E)–a key issue overlooked by the market, in our view.We also see continued industrial end-market weakness into FY20fromtheChina/US trade war, tariffsand supplier cost uncertainty. We downgrade to EqualWeight, reduce our price target to 210p, andcut our FY20/21E EPS by 11%/5% respectively (excluding a final ~£3m interest charge adjustment under IFRS 16). Weare 5%/14%/1low FY19/20/21E consensusEPS.

BE11:23am

Sorry that the words run together in Barclays notes, like it's a bad German translation. Not sure why that happens.

Omikin @punter, my personal knife catch is Anpario - down around 25% in two months.
BE11:23am

Spiritcutssupplier productionfrom 57 to 52/monthuntil FY21E. Senior suppliesBoeing and Spirit direct on the MAX programme, atan average shipset value of 300k.We expect Senior’s MAX production to fall to a Boeing/Spirit blended monthly rate of 47 (an 8%FY20E EBIT cut to BARC Aerospace estimates). Wecut FY19E/20E revenue by £8m/~£35m andlowerourFY20EAerospace margin by 50bps on overhead cost absorption. We expect this to bethe fourth consecutive year Seniorhas failedto deliver late-cycle, material Aerospace margin progression–a long-standing bear point.On our revised numbers, we are 180bps below the FY21E margin target of 13-14% which now appears unachievable,in our view.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Perhaps it's a kind of stealth watermark, like the Rap Genius apostrophe trick that caught Google leeching its lyrics?

BE11:24am

Valuation: The stock currently trades on FY20E consensus EV/EBITDA and P/E multiples of 6.9x/13x respectively(a ~15% discount to European A&D peers). We place the stock on a 25% discount (aFY20EEV/EBITDA target multipleof 6.0x) on a poorer returns profile (FY20E ROCE of 6.9% now materially lower than LT averageof 7.8%). This generates our revised price target of 210p.

The Guardian said this late on Tuesday https://www.thegua...stry-bribes-unaoil

BE11:33am

Prosecutors have dropped a criminal investigation into three businessmen who had been accused of paying huge bribes in the energy industry, sources with knowledge of the inquiry have said.

The Serious Fraud Office had been investigating claims that Unaoil, a firm formerly owned and controlled by its chairman Ata Ahsani and his sons Cyrus and Saman, paid multimillion-pound bribes to land contracts in the oil and gas industry.

On Tuesday, the SFO declined to say why its investigation into the trio had been dropped.

BE11:34am

Now, the official position of the SFO is not to comment on ongoing investigations.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

“We don’t comment on ongoing investigations,” their flack says.

BE11:35am

SUGGESTING. IF THEY CAN'T COMMENT, THE INVESTIGATION IS STILL ONGOING

Punter @Omikin, don't know Anpario but see today's AGM statement is reasonably positive, China has been a concern, but still fairly highly rated with m/cap c3 times sales.
Dec69 - Skeptic There's more incompetence....@BE, i'm speculating again, but perhaps the TRIO are helping land a 'bigger' bird.
BE11:35am

So we're still unclear as to whether The Grun (and MLex, which reported it first) have this correct.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

And of course, while the Petrofac investigation is linked to the Unaoil one, it's not the same.

BE11:37am

I'm sure I had Credit Suisse on this .... hang on.

BE11:37am

Petrofac risk would diminish but not go: The SFO’s investigation into
alleged corruption by Petrofac has been synonymous with Unaoil, with the
initial SFO press release saying that the case was related to its Unaoil
investigation. If the above article proves correct, the probability of the SFO
dropping its investigation into Petrofac, all things being equal, would
improve. However, the SFO has already seen Petrofac’s Head of Sales
convicted of 11 counts of bribery and it is not known whether all these cases pertain to Unaoil relationships. Hence, we do not think that the SFO
dropping its Unaoil investigation automatically means that Petrofac is
absolved of any wrong-doing

Are we there yet NHS Property is a known problem - at a local level within the CCGs and previously the PCTS it is a very political issue with GPs. All sort of vested interests
11:37 am
BE11:37am

132p negative valuation impact in our model: Our valuation for Petrofac
incorporates a negative 132p/sh (US$586m) for bribery-related fines. This assumes a US$821m payment, discounted over 4 years, with a 90% chance of a fine.

price move since the article was picked up this morning (+~50p), we
estimate, using the above inputs, that the market is now implying a 55%
probability of a fine.

BE11:47am

As for XPS Pensions, results are garbage.

XPS Pensions Group PLC (XPS:LSE): Last: 99.90, down 60.1 (-37.56%), High: 128.00, Low: 99.00, Volume: 5.00m
11:47 am
BE11:47am

Liberum's shop broker here. These are what the downgrades look like.

BE11:47am

Alongside the FY19 results, the company has provided updated guidance
for the short-term outlook for both revenues and costs. Although this results
in a 14% downgrade to our FY20 EPS, we believe that the benefits from a
stronger central function will place the company in a better position to take
advantage of the structural opportunities ahead. With the shares trading on
a CY20 PE of 15.6x (post-downgrades), it appears that the market was preempting some of this reset, and believe that the group is well placed to
outperform our conservatively struck forecasts. Our target price of 210p
(from 245p) reflects our belief in the long term fundamentals of the group,
although acknowledge short-term share price performance is likely to
require evidence of operational delivery

BE11:48am

Reported cash conversion of 70% was weaker than we had expected (85%) due to a larger than
expected working capital outflow (£3.8m vs. £2.0m) and the higher than expected cash exceptional
costs noted previously. As a result, despite lower than forecast capex, net debt of £51.5m was £6.6m
higher than anticipated and implied a leverage ratio of 1.9x at the end of FY19, down from the 2.5x
recorded at the end of FY18. Reflecting the acquisition of the Royal London asset announced earlier
this year, we expect a limited improvement in leverage in FY20, although anticipate this to fall to 1.4x
in FY21, absent any further M&A.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

So, the 14% cut breaks down like this:

BE11:48am

Reflecting the company’s outlook statement and the full year results we make the following changes
to our forecasts:
• Consistent with management guidance we assume no growth in the Pension business in
FY20 (from 7%) and expect a medium term growth rate of 3% in FY21 and beyond. Although
we still believe that this business demonstrates attractive growth characteristics, given the
FY19 performance such conservatism is appropriate, in our view. We note management
remains confident in this business’ ability to deliver +4% in the medium term
• We increase our revenue assumptions for the other divisions consistent with the revenue
outperformance delivered in FY19, with our underlying growth rates left broadly unchanged.
As a result we now forecast 5.5% revenue growth for the group in FY20 (vs. 9.0% previously)
and 4.5% in FY21 (vs. 7.2% previously)
• In line with management guidance we increase our estimate for central costs by c£2m in
FY20 to reflect the company’s decision to exit the discounted TSA arrangement early, as well
as its decision to further bolster its in-house capabilities including legal, HR and M&A
• Reflecting the shift in the mix in revenues we also reduce our medium term assumption on the
drop-through rates achievable in the business to 30%. This combined with the increase costs
results in our EBITDA margin forecasts decreasing by 2-3pp
• Reflecting the outperformance in FY19 we reduce our underlying tax rate assumption by
1.5pp to 17.5%
• Reduced our assumption for the average number of shares given the FY19 result
• Marginally increase our capex forecast to £2m in FY20 to reflect management guidance and
include a cash outflow of £4.8m relating to the recently announced Royal London acquisition.
The knock-on impact on the net debt position results in a marginal increase in our net interest
charge in all years.

BE11:49am

Buy tho.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

We believe that a DCF analysis represents the fairest way of valuing XPS given the stability and
visibility of its revenue streams. On this basis, we see the shares being worth 210p (from 245p),
implying a total return potential of 35%. The change in our target price reflects the negative impact of
the changes in our cash flow forecasts, partly offset by the roll-over of the DCF to FY20 (from FY19).
Long-term, we see material upside potential beyond this via the successful execution of the group’s
growth strategy. This view appears to be supported by the group’s relative rating, which also suggests
that the market under appreciates the highly visible, recurring and non-cyclical nature of the group’s
revenue and earnings.

undefined
BE11:50am

Was Greene King mentioned earlier? Full-year in line, which isn't a surprise post a trading update saying it would be.

11:50 am
BE11:51am

Outlook is for “another year of progress”, which is nice.

1966AndAllThat Any grey on Allied Minds with their AGM tomorrow? Their hawkeye investment makes Facebook privacy look cuddly
BE11:52am

Weather bad. Costs as expected. Debt getting eroded gradually.

BE11:52am

Here's Morgan Stanley.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

The company [is] expecting to limit cost inflation to a net £10-20m again (note H2 Pub Company margins were +50bps) but current trading in the first 8 weeks of the year has been negative due to the poor weather (we model +1% in FY20 and the CFO sounded comfortable with that). Leverage is down 0.2x, FCF more than covers capex, the dividend and debt repayment, and DSCR headroom has increased on the securitized debt. The new CEO mentions building on the existing strategy, suggesting no imminent strategic review or major change. Overall pretty unexciting, but the shares have rattled back in recent weeks and offer a secure 5.8% dividend yield and trade on an undemanding 8.7x P/E and 7.4x cal 20e.

BE11:53am

And Canaccord.

BE11:54am

Canaccord Genuity view
Greene King's FY19 PBT (Adj.) was £3m ahead of consensus and in line with our
forecasts. Looking forward, the year has started quietly versus tough prior year (long,
hot summer and World Cup) comparatives but this is reflected in our forecasts and we
anticipate no material change to consensus. Greene King has reiterated its dividend
policy of 2x cover and it remains sustainable on this basis, in our view. We retain our Buy
recommendation and 670p target price.
Detail
Greene King reported PBT (Adj.) of £246.9m (CGe £246.3m), +1.6% versus last year.
Managed pubs (70% of EBIT) performed respectably (EBIT +1.8%) but Pub Partners
(Tenanted & leased) pubs (-4.7%) and brewing (-10.7%) was uninspiring. In Managed
Pubs, Locals delivered +4.6% L4L growth and outperformed Destination & Premium as
their wet-led propositions were best placed to capture the trading conditions. Chef &
Brewer, with its big beer gardens, performed strongly, Hungry Horse reported positive
L4L sales but Farmhouse Inns, the carvery brand, suffered. We expect more normal
summer trading conditions this year, notwithstanding the 'African Plume' heatwave
heading towards the UK. Pub Partners profit decline mostly reflected the 5% reduction in
the number of pubs. In brewing, turnover grew by £12.5m but profit dropped by £3.3m to
£27.4m, reflecting higher costs and lower production volumes.
Greene King offset £35m of the £49m of cost pressures in FY19, cost pressures are
easing but Greene King still expects £40-50m of cost inflation (National Living Wage,
sugar and utilities taxes, business rates) with £30m-£40m of cost savings, pre- the
Value, Service, Quality initiative.
Capex dropped by £30m to £163m for the year as most of the re-branding is now
complete. Net debt fell by £89m and net debt/EBITDA is 4.0x which should continue
to edge down in future years as Greene King should be able to meet all its financial
obligations, including +£100m of dividend. Greene King continues to make progress
on unpicking the Spirit debenture and during the year it made £176m of unscheduled
repayments, it also terminated two interest rate swaps in line with the repayments. Since
year end it has given notice that it will repay the remaining 45% on the Spirit A4 secured
bond and will also terminate the related swap.
Valuation
At yesterday's close, Greene King is valued on 8.9x PE, 7.6x EV/EBITDA and 5.7%
dividend yield for FY20E, changing to 8.6x, 7.4x and 5.7% respectively for FY21E.
Our 670p share price target values Greene King on 10.6x PE, 8.3x EV/EBITDA , an
11.3% FCF yield and a 5.0% dividend yield, changing to 10.2x, 8.1x,11.5% and 5.0%
respectively. The PE multiples remain consistent with the 10-year average for the group.
The share price is underpinned by a forecast NAV of 678p for FY19E. The +£4.0m of SEorientated
freehold assets on the balance sheet underpins valuation, supported with
plenty of transaction evidence; the dividend is sustainable, in our view.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

BE11:57am

The leading cryptocurrency index, the CRYX (www.cryxindex.com) shows continued strong growth in the worlds leading currencies. The Index is currently +7.2%, implying a 40% gain in June'19 and +205% since the start of the year. As it sets new YTD highs we think it is fair to
assume it will have triggered interest and aided new client sign-ups at both these companies.
However, clients tend to be long so such strong gains are unlikely to have been helpful to the
Market P&L's. We are happy to re-iterate our SELL recommendations on both stocks. IGG trades on a consensus FY20 PE of 14.0x, falling to 12.6x and yields 7.4%. PLUS trades on a CY19 PE of 6.1x, rising to 6.6x and yields 9.8% falling to 9.0%. Our EPS forecasts are 29% below consensus in CY20.

andyalan10 Greene King' latest step down seemed to be on a broker repeating a longstanding same level target below everybody else's. Good to see some bounce back, but makes you wonder why it moved so far on no new news (perfect markets anyone?)

11:57 am
BE11:58am

... dunno, might be wrong, but doesn't look worth 8% off the price after 24 hours of consideration.

Omikin Esp. when you can't be doing with Spoons.
Tom Dalgleish @Punter, my theory on knife catching is that when nobody knows what ‘s going on it takes time to stabilise and volume to thin. Once certainty takes hold the SP goes somewhere

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

Haven't mentioned Thierry "Laboratoire" Garnier ......

BE12:01pm

Swapping Carrefour's Chinese business for B&Q's neverending quest to simplify its barbecue and softwood decking supply chains.

Kingfisher PLC (KGF:LSE): Last: 211.80, up 6 (+2.92%), High: 213.10, Low: 207.10, Volume: 2.63m
12:02 pm
BE12:03pm

Idea here, I think, is that he's French so he'll know what to do with France.

Tom Dalgleish I really think Bunnings could have beaten Kingfisher if not for Homestake. Bunnings has staples and a continuing rotation of differentiated products
BE12:03pm

As per Jefferies.

BE12:03pm

Given the extremely challenged French execution of recent years, the appointment of a French CEO at KGF's helm was always a more likely outcome. Mr Garnier's experience of large-scale store and supply chain change within an efficiently centralised group like Carrefour will be handy. So will his board exposure to Carrefour's successful domestic restructuring. French ops currently priced in at - £350m provide a scale of the opportunity he could help unlock.

Tom Dalgleish With Bunnings it’s not simplification. It’s range extension over time to bring people back
12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Our view remains that extremely poor French execution has been the main issue at KGF. We presume Mr Garnier will move rapidly to assess what went wrong (physical supply chain, systems, people?), and take corrective action. While the market will speculate on the extent to which this may require incremental margin efforts in the near term, our view remains that: 1) the consolidated structure of the French DIY retail market remains healthy, notwithstanding channel shift; 2) KGF's scale and asset base in the market (and for that matter high freehold ownership) give it the right to earn a respectable margin (vs the current, virtually 0% on a fully rented basis) and ROCE; and 3) the simplification of the two tier French brand approach should provide ample savings opportunities (beyond those stemming from recovering execution missteps). Valuing the UK on 6.8x 2019e EV/EBITDA and Poland on 7.4x implies France at -£350m.

Punter Many thanks BE for grey on XPS, seems it was too highly rated before because a 20 PE post downgrade even with good growth prospects from there does not suggest to me much s/term upside.

BE12:11pm

EasyJet’s shares have naturally reacted negatively to its 1 April profit warning, with the shares weak into and immediately after the print, prior to a rebound through the remainder of April. The nearly steady decline since suggests to us that, compounded by latent European macro and Brexit risk, the market is now pricing in a further profit warning at or before its 18 July Q3 results.

Tom Dalgleish TO you Upaswell. Directly to you
BE12:12pm

Contra to this market view, we believe that the Q3 results will be welcomed by the market, while consensus will fall within th (first-time) FY19 guidance range. Looking at the results in more detail, we are forecasting a marginal increase in Q3 unit revenue (constant currency Revenue Per Seat +0.6%), with ex-fuel unit costs down materially (EBNPPe -2.9%), partially due to an easy comp, but also ensuring the company remains on track to meet its guidance of FY unit costs declining y/y. Overall, we expect easyJet (assuming a similar PBT guidance range to Q318) to guide to FY19 PBT of GBP400-450m, with consensus (Bloomberg GBP428m) slotted safely within the range.

BE12:20pm

● Staffline belatedly released its FY 2018 results this morning, which were in
line with prevailing expectations. However, the real focus is clearly on the
outlook for 2019, the various reviews into the firm, and the balance sheet.
Today’s update notes the outlook for 2019 remains challenging but
maintains EBIT guidance in the £23m-28m range, consistent with that
given on 17 May. No further comment is given on the National Minimum
Wage (NMW) review, with management seeing the issue as “resolved”. We
see 2019 pre-equity raise net debt at £85m, c3.0x net debt/EBITDA. We
update our numbers for the moving parts since January, ultimately setting
adjusted EBIT at £24m for 2019. We await further clarity on the capital
structure after the proposed equity raise announced this morning and on
evidence of operational stabilisation.
● 2018: While now firmly in the rear view mirror, 2018 numbers were
actually in line with prevailing expectations. Staffing revenue came in a
£1,020m, up by 21% yoy, although the tough macro environment and its
exposure to retail and automotive-focused assets saw lower organic
growth. Divisional EBIT rose by 19% in the year. PeoplePlus has long been
the more difficult division, principally because of the lack of visibility and
longevity of its largest contributor, the Work Programme (WP). EBIT
declined by 21% here last year to £15m, but the bigger story is the decision
of the Department of Work and Pensions to buy out the remaining WP
contracts from the operators at the end of 2018.
● Current trading: Back in May, Staffline reduced its 2019 guidance to a
range of £23m-28m for adjusted EBIT, attributing the reduction to a shift
in its customers demand profiles away from temporary workers, a
slowdown in demand in higher-margin sectors such as automotive and
driving, and a weaker-than-expected pick-up in demand for work under
the Apprenticeship Levy. In our 2019 EBIT forecast of £24m we assume
£22m for Staffing but only £2m for PeoplePlus, highlighting that the key
delta versus the previous 2019 forecasts has been the significant reduction
in profitability in PeoplePlus.
● The future: After accounting for the reduced profitability and exceptional
cash flows relating to both the closure of the WP contracts and the NMW
investigation, we forecast net debt of £85m (before any assumed equity
raise). With a market cap of c£42m and an EBITDA multiple of 4.5x for
2019 and 3.2x for 2020 the shares have priced in a lot of the negativity –
understandably, given the high level of uncertainty. If management can
raise the equity required, stabilise the underlying trading performance, put
the NMW issues behind it and start to reduce debt, then a rebuild may be
possible. However, these are significant challenges to overcome and we
expect the stock to remain a special situation for the foreseeable future.
